scenes.dialogue_vo: Want an expert system in 60s? Meet CLIPS — facts, rules, agenda. Let's go!
scenes.on_screen_text:
Want an expert system in 60s?
Meet CLIPS — facts, rules, agenda
HOOK: Fast, rule-based, old-school cool ⚡️
Meme: Drake
  Reject: Spaghetti if-else chains
  Approve: Structured rules in CLIPS (use deftemplates!)

scenes.dialogue_vo: Quick definition: CLIPS is multi‑paradigm — rule-based, object-oriented and procedural — built for expert systems.
scenes.on_screen_text:
CLIPS = multi-paradigm
- Rule-based
- Object-oriented
- Procedural
Meme: Expanding Brain
  Level 1: raw facts
  Level 2: deftemplates
  Level 3: variables & wildcards
  Level 4: agenda + refraction + watch = poggers

scenes.dialogue_vo: Facts are the pieces of information. Deftemplates define the structure of those facts — think typed slots instead of messy free-form tuples.
scenes.on_screen_text:
FACTS + DEFTEMPLATES
Example:
(deftemplate person
  (slot name (type SYMBOL))
  (slot age  (type INTEGER)))
Meme: Drake
  Spaghetti if-else chains → ❌
  Structured rules in CLIPS → ✅

scenes.dialogue_vo: Add info with assert. Watch it pop into the fact-list — literal whoosh.
scenes.on_screen_text:
ASSERT A FACT
Terminal:
> (assert (person (name John) (age 30)))
> (facts)
  f-1     (person (name John) (age 30))
Tip: Use (deffacts) to define groups of initial facts
Code demo: (deffacts init
  (person (name John) (age 30)))

scenes.dialogue_vo: Rules: LHS are patterns, RHS are actions. If patterns match, the rule activates and goes to the agenda.
scenes.on_screen_text:
RULE = LHS ➜ RHS
Example:
(defrule check-adult
  (person (name ?n) (age ?a&:(>= ?a 18)))
  =>
  (printout t ?n " is an adult\n"))
Meme: Surprised Pikachu
  When a rule fires unexpectedly → Surprised Pikachu face

scenes.dialogue_vo: The inference engine matches facts to rules, puts activations on the agenda, and runs them. Inspect the agenda to understand order.
scenes.on_screen_text:
INFERENCE ENGINE FLOW
match → activate → agenda → fire
Useful commands:
> (agenda)    ; show activations
> (run)       ; execute
> (facts)     ; show facts
Debug tip: (watch facts rules activations)

scenes.dialogue_vo: Fields can be numbers, symbols, strings, or addresses. Use variables and wildcards to match flexibly — single-field ?var and multifield ?*rest.
scenes.on_screen_text:
FIELDS & VARIABLES
Types: numeric, symbol, string, address
Variables:
  ?x     single-field
  $?y    multifield (one or more)
  ?|z    (multifield in some dialects)
Example:
(defrule wild-demo
  (data (vals $?rest))
  => ... )
Meme: Expanding Brain — mastering wildcards = meta

scenes.dialogue_vo: Change facts with modify — or retract + assert if identity changes. Which to pick? It’s the Two Buttons dilemma.
scenes.on_screen_text:
MODIFY vs RETRACT+ASSERT
Two Buttons Meme
Button 1: (modify <fact-id> (age 31))
Button 2: (retract <id>)
         (assert (person (name John) (age 31)))
Rule: modify for tweaks, retract+assert for identity or major changes
Terminal:
> (modify 1 (age 31))

scenes.dialogue_vo: That rule firing twice? That's sus — refraction prevents a rule from firing repeatedly for the same facts unless something changes.
scenes.on_screen_text:
REFRACTION
Prevents repeated firing for the same fact set
If rule keeps firing:
  - inspect (agenda)
  - (watch activations)
  - check if facts are re-asserted
Meme: Distracted Boyfriend
  Girlfriend: watch & breakpoints
  Other girl: the agenda & refraction

scenes.dialogue_vo: Debug like a pro: watch facts, watch activations, check facts and the agenda, reproduce with deffacts, and set small tests.
scenes.on_screen_text:
DEBUGGING TOOLS
> (watch facts rules activations)
> (facts)
> (agenda)
Use deffacts to reproduce:
(deffacts test
  (person (name Alice) (age 17))
  (person (name Bob) (age 22)))
Tip: save a test file and load it to reproduce behaviors

scenes.dialogue_vo: Manage constructs: list, pretty-print, and undefine when needed. Peek inside rules with ppdefrule.
scenes.on_screen_text:
MANAGE CONSTRUCTS
Inspect:
  > (facts)
  > (agenda)
  > (ppdefrule check-adult)
Delete:
  > (undefrule check-adult)
  > (clear)  ; remove everything
Tip: keep workspace tidy to avoid ghost activations

scenes.dialogue_vo: Mini practical: deftemplate + deffacts + rule + run. Watch assert -> agenda -> fired action.
scenes.on_screen_text:
MINI EXAMPLE
(deftemplate person
  (slot name)
  (slot age))
(deffacts start
  (person (name Jane) (age 20)))
(defrule adult-msg
  (person (name ?n) (age ?a&:(>= ?a 18)))
  =>
  (printout t ?n " is adult\n"))
Terminal:
> (load "myrules.clp")
> (reset)
> (run)
Output: Jane is adult
Watch: (watch facts activations)

scenes.dialogue_vo: TL;DR: CLIPS = facts, templates, rules, agenda, and an inference engine. Use variables and wildcards for power, watch/refraction for sanity. Try it now!
scenes.on_screen_text:
TL;DR
- Facts (deftemplate / deffacts)
- Rules (LHS patterns → RHS actions)
- Inference engine + agenda
- Debug: (watch), (facts), (agenda)
- Use variables & multifield wildcards
Final Meme: Expanding Brain
CTA: Install CLIPS, run the mini example, and nerd out.
Call-to-action: Try these commands:
> (watch facts rules activations)
> (reset)
> (run)
Drop a comment: what rule made you say "Surprised Pikachu"?

asset.description: Drake Hotline Bling meme. Top panel (Drake rejecting): label text 'Spaghetti if-else chains' with a chaotic screenshot of deeply nested if-else code in a generic IDE behind him. Bottom panel (Drake approving): label text 'Structured rules in CLIPS (use deftemplates!)' with a clean CLIPS rules snippet and a simple facts list overlay. On-screen text above/below: 'Want an expert system in 60s? Meet CLIPS — facts, rules, agenda.'

bgm: Playful, upbeat lo-fi hip-hop with a light vinyl crackle and bouncy drums to set a fast, fun hook energy.

sfx.description: click-pop-when-watch-toggles-on.mp3 (as the Drake meme pops on screen)

asset.description: Expanding Brain meme with four stacked panels. Panel 1: Caption 'raw facts' over a tiny brain with scattered untyped tuples floating around. Panel 2: Caption 'deftemplates' over a slightly glowing brain with neatly boxed slot-based fact cards. Panel 3: Caption 'variables & wildcards' over a more radiant brain with ?x and $?rest beams connecting facts. Panel 4: Caption 'agenda + refraction + watch = poggers' over a cosmic galaxy brain, with a stylized CLIPS prompt and a glowing (agenda) window. Side text: 'CLIPS = multi-paradigm — Rule-based · Object-oriented · Procedural'.

bgm: Same playful lo-fi but add a subtle synth pad swell on each brain level to feel progressively 'bigger brain'.

asset.description: Drake Hotline Bling meme variant focused on code. Top panel with Drake hand out: overlay text 'Spaghetti if-else chains → ❌' and a blurry block of tangled if/else statements in a monospaced font behind him. Bottom panel with Drake smiling and pointing: overlay text 'Structured rules in CLIPS → ✅' next to a crisp CLIPS snippet showing (deftemplate person (slot name (type SYMBOL)) (slot age (type INTEGER))). Small caption footer: 'FACTS + DEFTEMPLATES'.

bgm: Same track continues; slightly filter the music for a half-beat then return to full to emphasize the code reveal.

asset.description: Start with a close-up, slightly shaky over-the-shoulder shot of a person in a dimly lit room aggressively typing on an absurdly small 1990s beige keyboard connected to a giant CRT monitor that hums faintly; the screen shows a monochrome terminal where the cursor blinks on a prompt. The camera slowly dollies in as the person types '(assert (person (name John) (age 30)))' with exaggerated finger movements, each keystroke oddly forceful. When they hit Enter, the monitor emits an exaggerated flash and the terminal text 'f-1 (person (name John) (age 30))' suddenly expands in size, stretching and wobbling like Jello before snapping back into place. The camera abruptly whip-pans to the side of the monitor where a tiny physical 'FACT LIST' sticky note is taped; new handwritten text 'f-1' appears on it by itself as if written by an invisible hand. The person nods in slow motion with comically serious concentration while the room’s lone desk plant vibrates slightly from the impact of the assert, and dust motes drift lazily through a narrow beam of light from an overhead fluorescent flickering in the background.

bgm: Keep the upbeat lo-fi but duck the volume slightly under typing, then swell up when the fact pops into the list.

asset.description: Surprised Pikachu meme. Top caption bar: 'When a rule fires unexpectedly'. Underneath, a cropped Surprised Pikachu face with big eyes and open mouth. On the side, a mini code box showing the sample rule '(defrule check-adult ...)' with LHS highlighted in one color and RHS in another, and a tiny arrow labeled 'LHS ➜ RHS ➜ agenda' pointing to Pikachu. Footer text: 'RULE = LHS ➜ RHS'.

bgm: Same playful track; add a brief comedic pause (music volume dip) right before Pikachu appears, then resume.

asset.description: Begin with a top-down view of a cluttered office desk where three pastel-colored index cards labeled 'facts', 'rules', and 'agenda' are laid out in a crooked row; a disembodied hand wearing an overly formal white glove slides the 'facts' card to the left and the 'rules' card to the right, then dramatically pushes a tiny toy conveyor belt between them as if assembling a factory. The camera slowly tilts closer as the hand places small paper arrows reading 'match', 'activate', 'agenda', and 'fire' onto the conveyor belt one by one, each arrow jittering slightly as though nervous. As the last arrow is placed, the camera cuts to a low, skewed angle from the desk surface showing a tiny paper 'activation' character—a stick figure doodle with a briefcase—riding along the conveyor toward a bulging index card labeled 'AGENDA' that shakes subtly. The stick figure reaches the agenda card and instantly duplicates into three identical copies that fan out, while the camera slowly crashes in for an uncomfortably close macro shot of the word 'fire' scribbled in red on the final arrow, the surrounding desk texture comically out of focus.

bgm: Light, rhythmic electronic track with a steady pulse to support the idea of a mechanical flow, but still playful.

asset.description: Custom Expanding Brain variant focusing on CLIPS variables. Panel 1: Caption 'numeric, symbol, string, address' with a small brain and four floating labels shaped like sticky notes. Panel 2: Caption '?x single-field' with a lit-up mid-size brain and a beam connecting ?x to a single slot. Panel 3: Caption '$?y multifield' with a larger glowing brain and ?y stretching to cover a whole list of values. Panel 4: Caption 'mastering wildcards = meta' with a galaxy brain overlaid with swirling sequences '(data (vals $?rest))' and arrows looping around, suggesting flexible matching.

bgm: Return to the earlier brainy pad-swell version of the lo-fi track; subtle rise with each panel.

asset_plan.scene_name: Scene 8 - Modify vs Retract+Assert Two Buttons

asset.description: Two Buttons meme. Top: Sweaty cartoon guy reaching toward two big red buttons. Left button labeled '(modify <fact-id> (age 31))' with a tiny sub-label 'tweak fields'. Right button labeled '(retract <id>) (assert (person ...))' with sub-label 'identity/major change'. The character’s face is slightly edited to have glasses and a 'CLIPS dev' name tag on his shirt. Bottom caption strip: 'Rule: modify for tweaks, retract+assert for identity or major changes'.

bgm: Keep the same groove; add a brief comedic drum fill as the character hesitates between the two buttons.

asset.description: Distracted Boyfriend meme. The boyfriend is labeled 'You debugging', the girlfriend he’s walking with is labeled 'watch & breakpoints', and the woman he’s turning to look at is labeled 'the agenda & refraction'. Add a small Among Us-style crewmate doodle in the corner labeled 'that rule firing twice = sus'. Header text above: 'REFRACTION — prevents repeated firing for the same fact set'.

bgm: Same playful track; add a slightly darker bass line layer to give a 'something’s sus' mood, still light.

asset.description: Open with an extreme close-up of a dusty keyboard key labeled 'F1' that has 'HELP' crudely written on it in marker; a single finger slowly presses it but nothing happens, and the camera awkwardly lingers. Smash cut to a bright, oversaturated shot of a laptop screen where a terminal window is open; thick neon-green text '(watch facts rules activations)' is already typed, and the cursor blinks in an oddly dramatic rhythm. The camera slowly rotates around the laptop in a full 180-degree arc as the user hits Enter, and multiple translucent copies of the commands '(facts)', '(agenda)', and '(watch ...)' float upwards from the screen like holographic speech bubbles, each wobbling before drifting off-frame. The scene then jump cuts to a tiny notebook propped against the laptop that has 'deffacts test' scribbled in giant letters; as the camera zooms in too far, the words '(person (name Alice) (age 17))' and '(person (name Bob) (age 22))' appear line by line as if being written by invisible ink, while a stray paperclip slowly slides down the notebook margin for no reason.

bgm: Slightly more focused, techy lo-fi with a hint of glitchy percussion to give a 'debugging toolkit' vibe, but still friendly.

sfx.description: small-pop-snap-when-lhs-and-rhs-labels-finish-drawing--visual-emphasis--mp3.mp3 (as each debug command caption locks in)

asset.description: Start on a wide shot of a chalkboard completely filled with nonsensical tiny rule names and arrows, looking like a conspiracy wall; the camera slowly creeps in as one rule name, 'check-adult', is circled three times in red chalk. Cut abruptly to a low-angle shot of a person sitting at a cramped desk in front of a terminal, lit only by the monitor glow; they dramatically type '(ppdefrule check-adult)' and lean in so close their nose is nearly touching the screen. The terminal output scrolls by but then the text visually floats off the monitor like a transparent sheet of paper and hovers above the desk. The person reaches up, grabs the floating rule with two fingers, crumples it like actual paper, and when they open their hand the crumple vanishes into thin air as a text overlay '(undefrule check-adult)' flashes near their fingers. Behind them, a corkboard pinned with sticky notes labeled 'facts', 'agenda', and 'rules' gradually fades to empty as if cleared by some unseen force, leaving only the faint ghost outlines of where notes used to be.

bgm: Slightly more minimal version of the core track, fewer drums, giving space for the 'ghost activation' joke to land.

asset.description: Begin with a straight-on shot of a tiny cardboard 'RULES MACHINE' box sitting on a table, hand-labeled with marker; in front of it are three index cards stacked: one titled 'deftemplate person', one 'deffacts start', and one 'defrule adult-msg'. A hand with way-too-big foam fingers on pulls the 'deftemplate person' card and dramatically feeds it into a slot in the box; the camera cuts to a close-up of the slot as the card disappears with a slight shudder. Next, the 'deffacts start' card is inserted, and faint LED fairy lights glued haphazardly inside the box flicker to life. The 'defrule adult-msg' card goes in last, after which the camera jump-cuts to a laptop screen beside the box showing a CLIPS prompt where the words '> (load "myrules.clp")', '> (reset)', and '> (run)' are already typed and highlighted sequentially by an animated yellow highlighter moving on its own. As '(run)' is highlighted, the cardboard box shakes in slow motion and a narrow strip of receipt paper ejects from a side slot with the text 'Jane is adult' printed in a huge dot-matrix font, curling dramatically onto the table while the camera tracks it in an overly serious cinematic close-up.

bgm: Upbeat, slightly triumphant version of the main track, maybe with a simple lead melody to sell this as the 'mini success story' moment.

asset_plan.scene_name: Scene 13 - TL;DR & Final Expanding Brain CTA

asset.description: Tall Expanding Brain-style stack for the TL;DR. Row 1: Small brain with caption '- Facts (deftemplate / deffacts)' and a simple card labeled 'FACT'. Row 2: Medium brain with caption '- Rules (LHS patterns → RHS actions)' and arrows from a fact card to a console printout. Row 3: Large brain glowing with caption '- Inference engine + agenda · Debug: (watch), (facts), (agenda)' and a cartoon agenda stack. Row 4: Galaxy brain with caption '- Use variables & multifield wildcards · Install CLIPS, run the mini example, and nerd out.' At the bottom, a CTA bar styled like a terminal with '> (watch facts rules activations) > (reset) > (run)' and a small comment bubble: 'What rule made you say "Surprised Pikachu"?'

bgm: Same upbeat track as Scene 12 but slightly lower volume to make room for VO and SFX; let it loop into an outro feel.

voice_timing.text: Want an expert system in 60s? Meet CLIPS — facts, rules, agenda. Let's go!
Quick definition: CLIPS is multi‑paradigm — rule-based, object-oriented and procedural — built for expert systems.
Facts are the pieces of information. Deftemplates define the structure of those facts — think typed slots instead of messy free-form tuples.
Add info with assert. Watch it pop into the fact-list — literal whoosh.
Rules: LHS are patterns, RHS are actions. If patterns match, the rule activates and goes to the agenda.
The inference engine matches facts to rules, puts activations on the agenda, and runs them. Inspect the agenda to understand order.
Fields can be numbers, symbols, strings, or addresses. Use variables and wildcards to match flexibly — single-field ?var and multifield ?*rest.
Change facts with modify — or retract + assert if identity changes. Which to pick? It’s the Two Buttons dilemma.
That rule firing twice? That's sus — refraction prevents a rule from firing repeatedly for the same facts unless something changes.
Debug like a pro: watch facts, watch activations, check facts and the agenda, reproduce with deffacts, and set small tests.
Manage constructs: list, pretty-print, and undefine when needed. Peek inside rules with ppdefrule.
Mini practical: deftemplate + deffacts + rule + run. Watch assert -> agenda -> fired action.
TL;DR: CLIPS = facts, templates, rules, agenda, and an inference engine. Use variables and wildcards for power, watch/refraction for sanity. Try it now!
